article.headline: Oklahoma undefeated despite injuries
article.linkText: Sooners win, but Jabahri Brown injured
article.story: NORMAN, Okla. (AP) -- Oklahoma had another win and another injury. Kevin Bookout scored a season-high 18 points and had 12 rebounds and Jaison Williams added 17 points for the Sooners (No. 8 ESPN/USA Today, No. 7 AP) in a 72-57 victory over Texas-Pan American on Monday night. The unbeaten Sooners (9-0) were hit with another injury, this time when center Jabahri Brown fell to the floor in the first half after being kicked in the face during a scramble for a rebound. He left the court holding the left side of his jaw and the senior did not return to the Oklahoma bench. Preliminary X-rays were inconclusive and Brown, who did not score in 10 minutes, was diagnosed with a sprained temporomandibular joint. "It was an accident," Oklahoma coach Kelvin Sampson said. "We're no different than a lot of teams. We've got some injuries. Somebody else has to step up." Playing in its second game as a Top Ten team, Oklahoma started the game with an 8-0 run. After a timeout, Texas-Pan American (3-9) went on a 14-8 run during which Chris Fagan hit three 3-pointers to help the Broncs pull within two points with 6:35 remaining. Texas-Pan American pulled within one on Ray Castillo's 3-pointer from the corner with 4:56 remaining in the first half, but it would be the closest the Broncs would get. Oklahoma closed the half on a 13-4 run to lead 37-25. Fagan led Texas-Pan American, which has lost six straight, with 13 points, while Sergio Sanchez had 11. DeAngelo Alexander had 16 points and 10 rebounds for the Sooners, his first double-double. Bookout has been hampered by a shoulder injury much of the season. "Kevin really came to play tonight. He really needed the rest over the break to heal up. He also used his practice time to improve his game," Sampson said. Bookout said the Sooners were hurt and helped by the holiday break. "The layoff hurt us just a little bit because we did not practice for five days. We needed every second of it because we have so many guys banged up," he said. "We need to work even harder now. Were back in the flow of things and we can see what we need to do." Starting guard Jason Detrick, playing in his first game back from a concussion, managed two points and four rebounds in 18 minutes for Oklahoma. Detrick has also battled an abdominal muscle tear. "This team has been so snake bit this year nobody has any idea what our team looks like," Sampson said. "Hopefully, we're getting away from all that voodoo." Texas-Pan American coach Bob Hoffman credited Oklahoma's defense. "The way we started and ended the first half was the difference in the game. We did not execute and we didn't get good shots and obviously that is because of Coach Sampson's defense," he said. "I was really proud of the effort our guys gave. Our effort has been there all year we just have to get better understanding and finishing plays when we get opportunities." The win was the 399th for Sampson, who is 223-81 in his 10th season at Oklahoma.
